content: Planning Area and HDB Town in Central Region, SingaporePlanning Area and HDB Town in Central Region, Singapore **Kallang** ([IPA](/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet): /ˈkɑːlɑːŋ, -ʌŋ/ *KAH-lung*) is a [planning area](/wiki/Planning_Areas_of_Singapore) and [residential zone](/wiki/New_towns_of_Singapore) located in the [Central Region](/wiki/Central_Region,_Singapore) of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). Development of the town is centered around the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River), the longest [river](/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Singapore) in Singapore. Kallang Planning Area is bounded by [Toa Payoh](/wiki/Toa_Payoh) in the north, [Geylang](/wiki/Geylang) in the east, [Marine Parade](/wiki/Marine_Parade) in the southeast, [Marina East](/wiki/Marina_East) in the south, the [Downtown Core](/wiki/Downtown_Core) in the southwest, [Rochor](/wiki/Rochor), [Newton](/wiki/Newton,_Singapore) in the west, and [Novena](/wiki/Novena,_Singapore) in the northwest. Throughout its history, Kallang was home to several national landmarks, some of which were built along the banks of the [Kallang Basin](/wiki/Kallang_Basin), including the [old National Stadium](/wiki/Former_National_Stadium,_Singapore) as well as the country's first purpose-built civil [airport](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Singapore), the [Kallang Airport](/wiki/Kallang_Airport). The famous Kallang Roar and Kallang Wave have roots traced to the former National Stadium, which hosted 18 [National Day Parades](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Parade), as well as numerous notable cultural and sporting events. As such, Kallang played a pivotal role in Singapore's aviation and sporting histories. Today, Kallang is best known as the location of the [Singapore Sports Hub](/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub), which is home to the [new National Stadium](/wiki/National_Stadium,_Singapore) and the [Singapore Indoor Stadium](/wiki/Singapore_Indoor_Stadium). The new National Stadium hosted the National Day Parade in 2016, while the Singapore Indoor Stadium frequently hosts concerts and performances. ## Etymology The area of what is now Kallang first appeared in an 1830 survey map of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) as "Kilang". By 1838, the place name was spelled as "Kelang". The modern-day "Kallang" is in use since 1842, even though the alternative spelling "Kalang" is also utilised in some instances. The [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language) and [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language) names for Kallang are "加冷" and "காலாங்" respectively. Both are direct [transliterations](/wiki/Transliteration) of the [English](/wiki/English_language)/Malay name. The Chinese word "加冷" is generally based on [Cantonese](/wiki/Cantonese) (pronounced as "加冷 gaa-laang") transliteration of the word "Kallang". Kallang was also nicknamed "火城" ("fire city") by the [Chinese community](/wiki/Chinese_Singaporeans) because it was the site of the [Kallang Gasworks](/wiki/Kallang_Gasworks). ## Geography ### Location Situated towards the southeastern shore of [Pulau Ujong](/wiki/Singapore_Island), the perimeter of **Kallang Planning Area** is made up of [Toa Payoh](/wiki/Toa_Payoh) in the north, [Geylang](/wiki/Geylang) in the east, [Marine Parade](/wiki/Marine_Parade) in the southeast, [Marina East](/wiki/Marina_East) in the south, the [Downtown Core](/wiki/Downtown_Core) in the southwest, [Rochor](/wiki/Rochor) and [Newton](/wiki/Newton,_Singapore) in the west, as well as [Novena](/wiki/Novena,_Singapore) in the northwest. Starting from the north in an anti-clockwise direction, the boundaries of Kallang Planning Area are marked by the [Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) (PIE), [Central Expressway](/wiki/Central_Expressway,_Singapore) (CTE), [Bukit Timah Road](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Road), Tekka Lane, Northumberland Road, Gloucester Road, Race Course Road, Rangoon Road, [Serangoon Road](/wiki/Serangoon_Road), Syed Alwi Road, Jalan Sultan, [Beach Road](/wiki/Beach_Road,_Singapore), [Ophir Road](/wiki/Ophir_Road), [East Coast Parkway](/wiki/East_Coast_Parkway) (ECP), Fort Road, Mountbatten Road, and Sims Way. Kallang Planning Area is part of the [Central Region](/wiki/Central_Region,_Singapore) of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). Although by definition a single "[planning area](/wiki/Planning_Areas_of_Singapore)" according to the [Urban Redevelopment Authority](/wiki/Urban_Redevelopment_Authority) (URA), the **Kallang/Whampoa New Town** as per the [Housing and Development Board](/wiki/Housing_and_Development_Board) (HDB) also includes the estate of [Whampoa](/wiki/Whampoa,_Singapore), located within [Balestier](/wiki/Balestier) subzone of the adjacent [Novena Planning Area](/wiki/Novena,_Singapore). Kallang/Whampoa is the only [HDB town](/wiki/New_towns_of_Singapore) that spans across two separate planning areas. ### Statistics Occupying an area of 9.17 square kilometres, Kallang Planning Area is ranked 32nd among the 55 [planning areas](/wiki/Planning_Areas_of_Singapore) in terms of total area, ahead of [Bukit Panjang Planning Area](/wiki/Bukit_Panjang) and behind [Punggol Planning Area](/wiki/Punggol). It is ranked 18th in terms of population size, ahead of [Queenstown Planning Area](/wiki/Queenstown,_Singapore) and behind Punggol Planning Area. With an area of 7.99 square kilometres, Kallang/Whampoa New Town is ranked 9th among the 23 [new towns](/wiki/New_towns_of_Singapore) in terms of total area, ahead of [Bukit Batok New Town](/wiki/Bukit_Batok) and behind [Bukit Merah New Town](/wiki/Bukit_Merah). ### Subdivisions Kallang Planning Area consists of nine "subzones", as officially established by the [Urban Redevelopment Authority](/wiki/Urban_Redevelopment_Authority) (URA) for [urban planning](/wiki/Urban_planning_in_Singapore) purpose. Similarly, the industrial zone bounded by MacPherson Road, Aljunied Road, the [Pelton Canal](/wiki/Kallang_River#Pelton_Canal) and [Pan Island Expressway](/wiki/Pan_Island_Expressway) (PIE) is part of the Kallang Way subzone. Despite the name of this subzone, it is now part of Geylang. Previously, this area formed part of the now-defunct Kallang [mukim](/wiki/Mukim#Singapore). The subzone of [Farrer Park](/wiki/Farrer_Park) belongs to the adjacent [Rochor Planning Area](/wiki/Rochor), even though the eponymous open field historically known as "Farrer Park" (now called "Farrer Park Field") is located within Kallang. While the subzones of [Little India](/wiki/Little_India,_Singapore) and [Kampong Glam](/wiki/Kampong_Glam) constitute parts of Rochor, many developments often associated with these two areas are located within Kallang, resulting in an "overspill" effect. "Little India" and "Kampong Glam" often refer to their respective cultural districts that are larger than the URA-defined subzones and extend into Kallang. The subzone of Lorong 8 Toa Payoh was known as "Kallang", possibly due to its location on either side of the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River). The subzone was later renamed to its current name, taken after a nearby road of the same name, and is a constituent part of [Toa Payoh Planning Area](/wiki/Toa_Payoh). ### Geology Kallang sits on the [Kallang Formation](/wiki/Geology_of_Singapore#Specific_areas) which consists of soft marine clay, loose alluvial muddy sand, loose beach sand, soft peaty and organic mud, and coral. Aside from the eponymous Kallang, the Kallang Formation is also found in other parts of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), particularly at river valleys, as well as around river mouths and coastal regions. ### Terrain The terrain of Kallang is generally flat and low, with elevation no more than 15 metres above sea level. Though not located within Kallang Planning Area, the geographic point of Bukit Kallang (also spelt as "Bukit Kalang") is a hill in the [Central Water Catchment](/wiki/Central_Water_Catchment) and has an elevation of 97 metres. Bukit Kallang is situated at the southeastern corner of the [Upper Peirce Reservoir](/wiki/Upper_Peirce_Reservoir), west of the TreeTop Walk suspension bridge, and within the territory of the former Ulu Kallang [mukim](/wiki/Mukim#Singapore). The [Bukit Kalang Service Reservoir](/wiki/Kallang_Service_Reservoir) maintained by the [Public Utilities Board](/wiki/Public_Utilities_Board_(Singapore)) (PUB) is within its vicinity, so is the source of the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River), the [Lower Peirce Reservoir](/wiki/Lower_Peirce_Reservoir). ### Water bodies The [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River) is the main [waterway](/wiki/List_of_waterways_in_Singapore) that meanders through Kallang. The source of the Kallang River is the [Lower Peirce Reservoir](/wiki/Lower_Peirce_Reservoir) (formerly known as the "Kallang River Reservoir"; renamed in honour of Municipal Engineer [Robert Peirce](/wiki/Robert_Peirce_(engineer)) in 1922) and the river mouth is located at [Kallang Basin](/wiki/Kallang_Basin), near to the [Merdeka Bridge](/wiki/Merdeka_Bridge,_Singapore). Flowing for more than 10 kilometres, the Kallang River is the longest river in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) and drains areas as far north as [Bishan](/wiki/Bishan,_Singapore) and [Ang Mo Kio](/wiki/Ang_Mo_Kio). The Kallang Basin is an enclosed bay in Kallang, and is a popular location for water sports. The [Singapore Sports Hub](/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub) is located on the eastern bank of the Kallang Basin. In 1977, the [Singapore government](/wiki/Government_of_Singapore) embarked on a ten-year-long clean-up project for the Kallang Basin and the nearby Singapore River, transforming them into the clean waterways of today. The Kallang Basin area used to form part of [mainland Singapore](/wiki/Pulau_Ujong)'s southeastern coastline, as evident from the location of [Beach Road](/wiki/Beach_Road,_Singapore). Kallang River used to empty into the [Singapore Straits](/wiki/Singapore_Straits) at Kallang Basin, as did Rochor River and Geylang River. One of the [Republic of Singapore Navy](/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Navy)'s (RSN) [Bedok-class mine countermeasures vessel](/wiki/Bedok-class_mine_countermeasures_vessel) is named "RSS *Kallang*", as part of a series of vessels named after Singapore's coastal regions. Kallang is also drained by the [Geylang River](/wiki/Geylang_River), [Rochor River](/wiki/Rochor_River), [Rochor Canal](/wiki/Rochor_Canal), [Marina Channel](/wiki/Marina_Channel), [Sungei Whampoa](/wiki/Kallang_River#Sungei_Whampoa) and the [Pelton Canal](/wiki/Kallang_River#Pelton_Canal), the latter two of which are [tributaries](/wiki/Kallang_River#Tributaries) of the Kallang River. These aforementioned waterways, together with the [Singapore River](/wiki/Singapore_River) and [Marina Bay](/wiki/Marina_Bay,_Singapore), make up the [Marina Reservoir](/wiki/Marina_Reservoir) that has a catchment size of about one-sixth of [mainland Singapore](/wiki/Singapore_Island)'s land area. Kallang constitutes part of the Drainage Catchments of Bukit Timah, Geylang, Stamford Marina and Kallang, as per the [Public Utilities Board](/wiki/Public_Utilities_Board_(Singapore)) (PUB). Kallang Drainage Catchment only extends into a small part of the Kallang Planning Area; it also encompasses areas belonging to the [planning areas](/wiki/Planning_Areas_of_Singapore) of [Toa Payoh](/wiki/Toa_Payoh), [Serangoon](/wiki/Serangoon), Bishan, Ang Mo Kio, [Central Water Catchment](/wiki/Central_Water_Catchment) and [Bukit Panjang](/wiki/Bukit_Panjang). Due to the high concentration of waterways in Kallang, many [bridges](/wiki/List_of_bridges_in_Singapore) were constructed to cross over these rivers and canals. Some famous bridges found in Kallang include the [Merdeka Bridge](/wiki/Merdeka_Bridge,_Singapore), [Benjamin Sheares Bridge](/wiki/Benjamin_Sheares_Bridge) (Singapore's tallest and longest bridge; reaches its highest point of 29 metres at Kallang Basin) and the Tanjong Rhu Footbridge (the first suspension bridge in Singapore). ## History ### Boundaries The present-day boundaries of Kallang Planning Area are established by the [Urban Redevelopment Authority](/wiki/Urban_Redevelopment_Authority) (URA) for urban planning purpose. Prior to the creation of "[planning areas](/wiki/Planning_Areas_of_Singapore)", [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) was divided into two types of survey districts by the [Singapore Land Authority](/wiki/Singapore_Land_Authority) (SLA): "*[mukim](/wiki/Mukim#Singapore)*" in rural areas and "town subdivisions" in the city. There were two mukim that bore the name "Kallang": Kallang and Ulu Kallang. #### Kallang mukim The [mukim](/wiki/Mukim#Singapore) of Kallang (alternatively spelled as "Kalang") was roughly bounded by Upper Serangoon Road, [Serangoon Road](/wiki/Serangoon_Road) and the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River) to its west; Upper Paya Lebar Road to its north and east; Paya Lebar Road to its east; and [Geylang Road](/wiki/Geylang_Road) to its south. The areas that once belonged to the former Kallang mukim are now split among the [planning areas](/wiki/Planning_Areas_of_Singapore) of [Serangoon](/wiki/Serangoon), [Toa Payoh](/wiki/Toa_Payoh), [Geylang](/wiki/Geylang) and Kallang. On the other hand, the areas that now form Kallang Planning Area were shared by the now-dissolved mukims of Toa Payoh, Geylang (formerly spelled as "Gelang"), Kallang and various town subdivisions. The modern boundaries of Kallang Planning Area therefore differ from those of the Kallang mukim. #### Ulu Kallang mukim A vast region at the upstream of the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River) was part of the [mukim](/wiki/Mukim#Singapore) of Ulu Kallang (also written as "Ulu Kalang"). *Ulu* is a [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language) term which translates to "rural", "remote", "upstream" or "origin" – a reference to its location at the upper reaches of the Kallang River and its relative lack of development. Within the boundaries of Ulu Kallang were [Upper Peirce Reservoir](/wiki/Upper_Peirce_Reservoir) and [Lower Peirce Reservoir](/wiki/Lower_Peirce_Reservoir). Ulu Kallang mukim bordered the adjacent mukims of Ulu Pandan in its southwest, Tanglin in its southeast, Toa Payoh and Ang Mo Kio in its east, South Seletar in its northeast, Mandai in its northwest, and Bukit Timah in its west. The territories which once constituted Ulu Kallang are now shared among the [planning areas](/wiki/Planning_Areas_of_Singapore) of [Central Water Catchment](/wiki/Central_Water_Catchment), [Bukit Timah](/wiki/Bukit_Timah) and [Bishan](/wiki/Bishan,_Singapore), the first of which remained as one of the least developed places in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). In several historical maps, this mukim was labeled as "Upper Kalang". ### Landscape The present landscape of Kallang is the result of extensive [land reclamation](/wiki/Land_reclamation_in_Singapore) carried out over multiple phases. Prior to land reclamation, the original southeastern shoreline of [mainland Singapore](/wiki/Singapore_Island) was situated at the [Kallang Basin](/wiki/Kallang_Basin) area, near where Tanjong Rhu Road and [Beach Road](/wiki/Beach_Road,_Singapore) are today. In August 1931, the Public Works Department was tasked to lead the land reclamation project at the eastern portion of the Kallang Basin for the construction of the [Kallang Airport](/wiki/Kallang_Airport). A total of 339 acres of mangrove swamp was reclaimed, and the project cost was estimated at 9 million [Straits dollars](/wiki/Straits_dollar). The land reclamation lasted from May 1932 to October 1936. In June 1932, another land reclamation project began at Beach Road. The aim was to create a foreshore to the immediate south of Beach Road between [Stamford Road](/wiki/Stamford_Road) and the [Rochor River](/wiki/Rochor_River). From 1963 to 1971, the [Housing and Development Board](/wiki/Housing_and_Development_Board) (HDB) led a massive land reclamation project in the northern part of the Kallang Basin. The swamps and mudflats were filled in using earth sourced from the leveled hills of [Toa Payoh](/wiki/Toa_Payoh). Before land reclamation, the Kallang Basin was a large swamp that stretched as far north as today's Bendemeer Road at its greatest extent; numerous islands existed along the course of the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River) and its [tributaries](/wiki/Kallang_River#Tributaries). Between 1966 and 1975, the East Coast Reclamation Project led by HDB formed new lands at [Tanjong Rhu](/wiki/Tanjong_Rhu) in southern Kallang, as well as the adjacent communities in [Marine Parade](/wiki/Marine_Parade). In 1979, Phase VI of the project extended the Tanjong Rhu coast southwards, forming what is today's [Marina East](/wiki/Marina_East). ### Settlements Historically, Kallang was home to some of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)'s earliest settlers. Numerous villages could be found at the Kallang Basin area before modern developments took place: Kampong Kallang Pasir, Kampong Kallang Pokok, Kampong Kallang Laut, Kampong Kallang Batin, Kampong Kallang Rokok, [Kampong Bugis](/wiki/Kampong_Bugis), Kampong Soo Poo (also the name of a now-expunged road, located off [Kallang Road](/wiki/Kallang_Road)) and Kampong Koo Chye. Today, some of their legacies are still seen – roads such as Padang Jeringau and Kampong Bugis that branch out from Kallang Road directly reference these expunged villages. In the 1950s, housing in Singapore was insufficient for its growing population. A large portion of the population was living in slum-like places with poor sanitation. As the [city area](/wiki/City_of_Singapore_(historical_entity)) became congested, the [colonial government](/wiki/Colony_of_Singapore) decided to build new public housing estates to tackle the problem. One of the plans was to develop Kallang into Singapore's equivalent of the [Hyde Park](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London), as reported by *[The Straits Times](/wiki/The_Straits_Times)* in an article dated 11 March 1955. These residential developments are known collectively as the "Old Kallang Airport Estate", located along [Old Airport Road](/wiki/Old_Airport_Road,_Singapore) and [Dakota Crescent](/wiki/Dakota_Crescent). The low-rise residential blocks at Dakota Crescent are known for their unique [architecture](/wiki/Architecture_of_Dakota_Crescent). ### Significant events On 4 December 1919, [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) witnessed its first-ever aircraft landing at the [Farrer Park Field](/wiki/Farrer_Park_Field), when [Captain Ross Smith](/wiki/Ross_Macpherson_Smith) and three other crew members touched down in a [Vickers Vimy](/wiki/Vickers_Vimy) en route to [Darwin](/wiki/Darwin,_Northern_Territory), [Australia](/wiki/Australia). This event kickstarted Singapore's aviation journey. On 17 February 1942, the troops of the [British Indian Army](/wiki/British_Indian_Army) officially surrendered to the [Imperial Japanese Army](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army) represented by [Major Fujiwara Iwaichi](/wiki/Fujiwara_Iwaichi) at the Farrer Park Field as part of an event now called the "[Farrer Park address](/wiki/Farrer_Park_address)". [Captain Mohan Singh](/wiki/Mohan_Singh_(general)) later declared the formation of the [First Indian National Army](/wiki/First_Indian_National_Army) and openly recruited volunteers to fight against the [British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj) for the [independence of India](/wiki/Indian_independence_movement). On 29 June 1946, one of the [Dakota](/wiki/Douglas_DC-3) aircraft belonging to the [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force) (RAF) crashed at the [Kallang Airport](/wiki/Kallang_Airport) in a thunderstorm, killing all 20 that were on board. Officially named in 1957, [Dakota Crescent](/wiki/Dakota_Crescent) and Dakota Close serve to commemorate this aviation disaster. On 13 March 1954, a [Lockheed L-749A Constellation](/wiki/Lockheed_L-749A_Constellation) aircraft operated by the [British Overseas Airways Corporation](/wiki/British_Overseas_Airways_Corporation) (BOAC) [crashed](/wiki/1954_BOAC_Lockheed_Constellation_crash) and exploded as it attempted landing at the Kallang Airport, killing 33 passengers and crew. On 15 August 1955, the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP) campaigned for [self-governance](/wiki/Self-governance_of_Singapore) at the Farrer Park Field. On 18 March 1956, some 20,000 people gathered at the Kallang Airport complex for a [*merdeka*](/wiki/Merdeka#Singapore) ([Malay](/wiki/Malay_language) for "freedom") rally organised by then-[Chief Minister](/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Singapore) [David Marshall](/wiki/David_Marshall_(Singaporean_politician)). The event later turned into a riot, causing at least 50 cases of injuries. This riot discredited Marshall in the eyes of the [British](/wiki/British_people), thereby hindered Singapore's independence progress and led to Marshall's subsequent resignation. Described as "the worst and prolonged in Singapore's post-war [history](/wiki/History_of_Singapore)", the infamous [1964 Singapore race riots](/wiki/1964_race_riots_in_Singapore) broke out in Kallang on 21 July 1964, at the intersection of [Kallang Road](/wiki/Kallang_Road) and Padang Jeringau, around the former Kampong Soo Poo. On 23 February 1970, a time capsule was buried at the [old National Stadium](/wiki/Former_National_Stadium,_Singapore) by then-Minister for [Finance](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(Singapore)) [Goh Keng Swee](/wiki/Goh_Keng_Swee). The capsule was never found despite more than three years of search. On 15 February 2016, a new time capsule was laid underground at the [Singapore Sports Hub](/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub). It is expected to be unearthed in 2040. The old National Stadium that once stood on the same plot of land as the current [Singapore Sports Hub](/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub) was the ceremony venue for the [Southeast Asian Games](/wiki/Southeast_Asian_Games) in (/wiki/1973_Southeast_Asian_Games), (/wiki/1983_Southeast_Asian_Games) and (/wiki/1993_Southeast_Asian_Games). The old National Stadium hosted the [National Day Parade](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Parade) (NDP) a total of 18 times (in 1976, 1980, 1985, 1986, 1988, 1989, 1991, 1992, 1994, 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004 and 2006). From 1986 to 2000, former [Singapore Prime Ministers](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore) [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) and [Goh Chok Tong](/wiki/Goh_Chok_Tong) held their annual [National Day Rally](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Rally) at the [Kallang Theatre](/wiki/Kallang_Theatre). On 20 April 2004, a section of [Nicoll Highway](/wiki/Nicoll_Highway) collapsed in an accident now known as the [Nicoll Highway collapse](/wiki/Nicoll_Highway_collapse). The road itself and surrounding area sunk in, snapping gas, water and electricity cables, thereby cutting off power in the nearby [Suntec City](/wiki/Suntec_City) and [Marina Bay](/wiki/Marina_Bay,_Singapore) areas. Tenants and residents of [Golden Mile Complex](/wiki/Golden_Mile_Complex) were evacuated. The completion of the [Circle Line](/wiki/Circle_Line_(Singapore)) was pushed back by a year, and the original site of [Nicoll Highway MRT station](/wiki/Nicoll_Highway_MRT_station) which was 100 metres away from the current station had to be abandoned. The section of tracks between [Promenade MRT station](/wiki/Promenade_MRT_station) and [Stadium MRT station](/wiki/Stadium_MRT_station) had to be realigned. The collapse killed four people. During the [2010 Summer Youth Olympics](/wiki/2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), the [archery](/wiki/Archery_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics), [tennis](/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) and [football](/wiki/Football_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics) games were held at [Kallang Field](/wiki/Kallang_Field), [Kallang Tennis Centre](/wiki/Kallang_Tennis_Centre) and [Jalan Besar Stadium](/wiki/Jalan_Besar_Stadium) respectively. The opening and closing ceremonies of the [2015 Southeast Asian Games](/wiki/2015_Southeast_Asian_Games) were held at the [new National Stadium](/wiki/National_Stadium,_Singapore). Numerous matches also took place at various venues across Kallang. On 9 August 2016, the new National Stadium hosted the 2016 NDP – the first NDP in the new National Stadium, and the first NDP held in Kallang after a decade of hiatus. ### Raffles' landing There is a dispute pertaining to the exact location where the founder of modern [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), [Sir Stamford Raffles](/wiki/Stamford_Raffles), first [landed](/wiki/Founding_of_modern_Singapore#Raffles'_landing_and_arrival) on [mainland Singapore](/wiki/Pulau_Ujong) in 1819. Even though the [Raffles' Landing Site](/wiki/Raffles%27_Landing_Site) by the [Singapore River](/wiki/Singapore_River) is generally believed to be the original landing point, other sources challenge that claim. Based on the record in the Cho Clan Archives, Raffles could have landed at the [Kallang Basin](/wiki/Kallang_Basin) instead, in what is today's [Kallang Riverside Park](/wiki/Kallang_Riverside_Park). ## Landmarks Kallang is home to numerous "historic sites" of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), as officially designated by the [National Heritage Board](/wiki/National_Heritage_Board_(Singapore)) (NHB). These include the [Central Sikh Temple](/wiki/Central_Sikh_Temple) along Towner Road, the former [Kallang Gasworks](/wiki/Kallang_Gasworks) along [Kallang Road](/wiki/Kallang_Road), the [Merdeka Bridge](/wiki/Merdeka_Bridge,_Singapore) along [Nicoll Highway](/wiki/Nicoll_Highway), the Balestier Plain along Balestier Road, the old [Kallang Airport](/wiki/Kallang_Airport) along Stadium Link, the historic Farrer Park (now called "[Farrer Park Field](/wiki/Farrer_Park_Field)") along Rutland Road, as well as the [Jalan Besar Stadium](/wiki/Jalan_Besar_Stadium) along Tyrwhitt Road. The [Urban Redevelopment Authority](/wiki/Urban_Redevelopment_Authority) (URA) has identified numerous areas in Singapore as "conservation areas", a few of which can be found in Kallang. These include the Former Kallang Airport Conservation Area and the [Jalan Besar](/wiki/Jalan_Besar) Conservation Area, where structures of historical, architectural and cultural significance are carefully conserved. The [Geylang](/wiki/Geylang) Conservation Area extends partially into Kallang, consisting mainly of [shophouses](/wiki/Architecture_of_Singapore#Shophouse) fronting the stretch of [Geylang Road](/wiki/Geylang_Road) between Sims Way and Lorong 1 Geylang. ### Modern landmarks Arguably the most famous landmark in modern Kallang is the [Singapore Sports Hub](/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub), comprising the [new National Stadium](/wiki/National_Stadium,_Singapore), the [Singapore Indoor Stadium](/wiki/Singapore_Indoor_Stadium), the [Kallang Wave Mall](/wiki/Kallang_Wave_Mall), and several other sports facilities. Built at an estimated cost of S$1.3 billion, the Singapore Sports Hub frequently hosts national and international sporting, cultural and entertainment events. The [Merdeka Bridge](/wiki/Merdeka_Bridge,_Singapore) crosses over the [Kallang Basin](/wiki/Kallang_Basin) at the mouths of the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River) and [Rochor River](/wiki/Rochor_River). Initially conceived as the "Kallang Bridge", the Merdeka Bridge was considered as a symbol of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)'s aspiration for independence in the 1950s. A pair of stone lions called the "[Merdeka Lions](/wiki/Merdeka_Bridge,_Singapore#Merdeka_Lions)" once stood at each end of the bridge from 1956 to 1966. These lion statues are now standing at the [SAFTI Military Institute](/wiki/SAFTI_Military_Institute). The [Kallang Airport](/wiki/Kallang_Airport) was Singapore's first purpose-built civil [airport](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Singapore), operating from 1937 to 1955. Hailed as the "finest airport in the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire)", it was also praised by renowned aviator [Amelia Earhart](/wiki/Amelia_Earhart) as "an aviation miracle of the East". Several structures of the Kallang Airport were gazetted for conservation on 5 December 2008. Today, the complex is fenced off from public access. The [Golden Mile Complex](/wiki/Golden_Mile_Complex) along [Beach Road](/wiki/Beach_Road,_Singapore) is a prominent landmark in the area. It was one of the [Singapore government](/wiki/Government_of_Singapore)'s first urban renewal projects, combining commercial and residential spaces into one building. It was described by famous [English](/wiki/English_people) architectural critic [Reyner Banham](/wiki/Reyner_Banham) as "an exemplary type of megastructure". The congregation of the [Thai](/wiki/Thai_people) community at Golden Mile Complex also gives it the nickname "Little [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand)". The surrounding area is termed "the Golden Mile", a strip of high-rise commercial land fronting the Kallang Basin. Chwee Kang Beo Temple (水江庙), which means ‘Water River Temple’ has been at the present location since the late 1940s. It is a unique landmark along Kallang riverside, at Upper Boon Keng Road. The [Central Sikh Temple](/wiki/Central_Sikh_Temple) is Singapore's first [Sikh](/wiki/Sikh) [gurdwara](/wiki/Gurdwara), originally established in 1912. Its current site at Towner Road was officially opened in November 1986. The [Sri Srinivasa Perumal Temple](/wiki/Sri_Srinivasa_Perumal_Temple) along [Serangoon Road](/wiki/Serangoon_Road) was gazetted as a national monument on 10 November 1978. The main factory building of the former National Aerated Water Company along Serangoon Road has also been gazetted for conservation, and will be integrated into a future residential development. ### Former landmarks The [Kallang Gasworks](/wiki/Kallang_Gasworks) was the first to be built in Singapore to supply gas for street lighting. Constructed in 1862, the facilities were operated by the Singapore Gas Company (now called "[City Gas](/wiki/City_Gas)") and produced gas uninterruptedly for over 130 years, except for brief pauses during [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I) and [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II). It was decommissioned on 23 March 1998, and all operations were taken over by the Senoko Gasworks in [Sembawang](/wiki/Sembawang). Today, a sculpture titled *Spirit of Kallang* by Singaporean artist Lim Leong Seng is standing in the [Kallang Riverside Park](/wiki/Kallang_Riverside_Park) to commemorate the Kallang Gasworks. Built on the runway site of the former [Kallang Airport](/wiki/Kallang_Airport) prior to the development of the [old National Stadium](/wiki/Former_National_Stadium,_Singapore), the now-demolished [Kallang Park](/wiki/Kallang_Park) was a large public park that consisted of children's playgrounds, a fountain gifted by the [Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry](/wiki/Singapore_Chinese_Chamber_of_Commerce_and_Industry) (SCCCI), carnival booths and the popular Wonderland Amusement Park. Originally proposed by then-Minister for [National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)) [Ong Eng Guan](/wiki/Ong_Eng_Guan) under "Project Lung", the Kallang Park was the first attempt at redeveloping the lands previously occupied by the Kallang Airport. Kallang was also the location of three of Singapore's most iconic amusement parks: [New World Amusement Park](/wiki/New_World_Amusement_Park), [Gay World Amusement Park](/wiki/Gay_World_Amusement_Park) and Wonderland Amusement Park. The first was situated near present-day [City Square Mall](/wiki/City_Square_Mall_(Singapore)); the second was located on the open field bounded by [Geylang Road](/wiki/Geylang_Road), Sims Way, Kallang Airport Way and Kallang Airport Drive; and the third was part of the old Kallang Park. The [former National Stadium](/wiki/Former_National_Stadium,_Singapore) played host to numerous cultural, sporting and national events, including the [National Day Parade](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Parade) (NDP) for a total of 18 times. Celebrated as be the birthplace of the famous Kallang Roar and Kallang Wave, the former National Stadium was home to the [Singapore FA](/wiki/Singapore_FA) (nicknamed "the Lions") and the nearby shopping mall is named [Kallang Wave Mall](/wiki/Kallang_Wave_Mall). ## Politics Between 1959 and 1991, Kallang mostly came under [Kallang Single Member Constituency](/wiki/Kallang_Single_Member_Constituency) (SMC). Its Members of Parliament (MP) included [Suppiah Dhanabalan](/wiki/S._Dhanabalan), who served as [Minister](/wiki/Minister_for_Foreign_Affairs_(Singapore)) for [Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Singapore)) and [Minister](/wiki/Minister_for_National_Development_(Singapore)) for [National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)) during his service as MP for Kallang SMC. Other constituencies that historically covered various parts of Kallang included the [Geylang West SMC](/wiki/Geylang_West_Single_Member_Constituency), [Jalan Besar SMC](/wiki/Jalan_Besar_Single_Member_Constituency) and [Kolam Ayer SMC](/wiki/Kolam_Ayer_Single_Member_Constituency). From 2011 to 2015, large parts of Kallang were part of the short-lived [Moulmein-Kallang Group Representation Constituency](/wiki/Moulmein-Kallang_Group_Representation_Constituency) (GRC), which was co-led by Minister for [Communications and Information](/wiki/Ministry_of_Communications_and_Information) [Yaacob Ibrahim](/wiki/Yaacob_Ibrahim) and Minister for [Transport](/wiki/Ministry_of_Transport_(Singapore)) [Lui Tuck Yew](/wiki/Lui_Tuck_Yew). The area bounded by Sungei Whampoa, [Serangoon Road](/wiki/Serangoon_Road), Balestier Road and the [Central Expressway](/wiki/Central_Expressway,_Singapore) (CTE) formed part of [Whampoa Single Member Constituency](/wiki/Whampoa_Single_Member_Constituency) (SMC). [Tanjong Rhu](/wiki/Tanjong_Rhu) was under [Mountbatten SMC](/wiki/Mountbatten_Single_Member_Constituency). Both Moulmein-Kallang GRC and Whampoa SMC came under the administration of the now-dissolved Moulmein-Kallang Town Council, which was headquartered at the same [Geylang Bahru](/wiki/Geylang_Bahru) office currently used by Jalan Besar Town Council. As of the [2020 Singapore general election](/wiki/2020_Singapore_general_election), the political representation of Kallang in the [Parliament of Singapore](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) was split among three [electoral constituencies](/wiki/Constituencies_of_Singapore). The vast majority of Kallang forms part of [Jalan Besar GRC](/wiki/Jalan_Besar_Group_Representation_Constituency); part of [Kampong Java](/wiki/Kampong_Java) subzone comes under [Tanjong Pagar GRC](/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar_Group_Representation_Constituency); and the entirety of [Tanjong Rhu](/wiki/Tanjong_Rhu) subzone is part of [Mountbatten SMC](/wiki/Mountbatten_Single_Member_Constituency). These constituencies were held by [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)'s ruling [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP). Jalan Besar Town Council is responsible for the maintenance of the areas that come under Jalan Besar GRC; Tanjong Pagar Town Council maintains areas belonging to Tanjong Pagar GRC; and Mountbatten SMC is administered by Marine Parade Town Council. The main office of Jalan Besar Town Council is located in Kallang, at 70 [Geylang Bahru](/wiki/Geylang_Bahru). ## Economy ### Commercial Unlike most [Singaporean towns](/wiki/New_towns_of_Singapore), Kallang does not have an integrated town centre. Instead, its commercial activities are largely concentrated at the [Singapore Sports Hub](/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub), as well as within the subzones of [Lavender](/wiki/Lavender,_Singapore) and [Crawford](/wiki/Crawford,_Singapore). The Singapore Sports Hub vicinity is home to two [shopping destinations](/wiki/List_of_shopping_malls_in_Singapore), [Leisure Park Kallang](/wiki/Leisure_Park_Kallang) and [Kallang Wave Mall](/wiki/Kallang_Wave_Mall), as well as a [cultural venue](/wiki/List_of_arts_and_entertainment_venues_in_Singapore), the [Kallang Theatre](/wiki/Kallang_Theatre). Other than retail outlets, Leisure Park Kallang also has a cinema, an ice skating rink and a bowling alley. Various other shopping malls such as the [City Square Mall](/wiki/City_Square_Mall_(Singapore)) along Kitchener Road, [Mustafa Centre](/wiki/Mustafa_Centre) along Syed Alwi Road and Aperia Mall along Kallang Avenue are also situated within the boundaries of Kallang. In recent years, areas along [Beach Road](/wiki/Beach_Road,_Singapore) and Jalan Sultan have seen new commercial developments, such as [The Concourse](/wiki/The_Concourse) and City Gate, due to their close proximities to the adjacent [Central Area](/wiki/Central_Area,_Singapore). The high rent in the Central Area also makes Kallang an attractive location for offices, particularly office spaces along Kallang Avenue, Lavender Street and Beach Road. Examples of renowned companies that have offices in Kallang include [German](/wiki/Germany) automotive firm [Continental AG](/wiki/Continental_AG), [American](/wiki/United_States) technology company [Micron Technology](/wiki/Micron_Technology), [Japanese](/wiki/Japan) consumer goods manufacturer [Lion Corporation](/wiki/Lion_Corporation), American fast food group [Yum! Brands](/wiki/Yum!_Brands), [French](/wiki/France) energy management and automation solutions corporation [Schneider Electric](/wiki/Schneider_Electric), and the [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)-based environmental solutions enterprise [Hyflux](/wiki/Hyflux). ### Industries Kallang is currently home to numerous light industrial estates. Many heavy industry factories have been relocated away from this area to promote residential and commercial use. Today, most of Kallang's industrial estates are clustered at Kallang Avenue, [Kallang Bahru](/wiki/Kallang_Bahru), Kallang Place, Kallang Junction, Kallang Sector and Kallang Way. There are plans to redevelop Kallang's industrial zones into [mixed-use developments](/wiki/Mixed-use_development), including a hub for high-value and knowledge-based businesses called the "Kallang iPark". Prior to modern developments, Kallang was home to a booming shipbuilding industry, particularly due to its coastal location and the presence of numerous waterways in the area. Shipbuilding companies were found around present-day Upper Boon Keng Road and [Jalan Benaan Kapal](/wiki/Jalan_Benaan_Kapal) (literally "Ship Construction Road" in [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language)). In particular, the latter was the location of the first purpose-built marine industrial estate in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), before the area was transformed into a sporting and lifestyle precinct. Across the [Geylang River](/wiki/Geylang_River), numerous shipbuilding companies, including [John I. Thornycroft & Company](/wiki/John_I._Thornycroft_%26_Company) and Singapore Slipway, once straddled the coast of [Tanjong Rhu](/wiki/Tanjong_Rhu). ## Infrastructure ### Education The following educational institutions are located within Kallang: - [Dunman High School](/wiki/Dunman_High_School) - Hong Wen School - Bendemeer Primary School - Farrer Park Primary School - [NorthLight School](/wiki/Northlight_School) - [Umar Pulavar Tamil Language Centre](/wiki/Umar_Pulavar_Tamil_Language_Centre) 3 Geylang Bahru Lane was frequently used by the [Ministry of Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)) (MOE) as a temporary school compound, and hosted such schools as [Victoria School](/wiki/Victoria_School), [Cedar Girls' Secondary School](/wiki/Cedar_Girls%27_Secondary_School), [SJI Junior](/wiki/St._Joseph%27s_Institution,_Singapore) and [CHIJ Katong Convent](/wiki/CHIJ_Katong_Convent). This site is now used by the [Singapore Examinations and Assessment Board](/wiki/Singapore_Examinations_and_Assessment_Board) (SEAB) as its office. The current site of NorthLight School used to be the former [Balestier](/wiki/Balestier) campus of the [Institute of Technical Education](/wiki/Institute_of_Technical_Education) (ITE). ### Healthcare The following [hospitals](/wiki/List_of_hospitals_in_Singapore) are located within Kallang: - [KK Women's and Children's Hospital](/wiki/KK_Women%27s_and_Children%27s_Hospital) - Kwong Wai Shiu Hospital The [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore)) (MOH) has announced an upcoming polyclinic in Kallang, expected to be ready by 2020. The polyclinic will be housed in a 10-storey facility and integrated with a chronic sick unit, the first of such integrated healthcare building in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). ### Community spaces Managed by the [People's Association](/wiki/People%27s_Association_(Singapore)) (PA), each "community club" or "community centre" (CC) serves around 15,000 households. The following CCs are located at Kallang: - Geylang West Community Club - Jalan Besar Community Club - Kallang Community Club - Kampong Glam Community Club - Katong Community Centre - Kolam Ayer Community Club - PAssion WaVe @ Marina Bay - Pek Kio Community Centre The PA headquarters is also situated in Kallang, along King George's Avenue. ### Parklands The [Kallang Riverside Park](/wiki/Kallang_Riverside_Park) is a riverine [park](/wiki/List_of_parks_in_Singapore) located at the mouths of the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River) and [Rochor River](/wiki/Rochor_River). The sections on either side of the Kallang River are managed by the [National Parks Board](/wiki/National_Parks_Board) (NParks), while the section along the western bank of the Rochor River was absorbed into [Gardens by the Bay](/wiki/Gardens_by_the_Bay) as part of Bay Central Garden. The [Marina Promenade](/wiki/Marina_Promenade,_Singapore) on the western banks of the [Kallang Basin](/wiki/Kallang_Basin) and [Marina Channel](/wiki/Marina_Channel) links Kallang Riverside Park in the north with [Marina Centre](/wiki/Marina_Centre) in the south. It forms part of the Bay Central Garden of Gardens by the Bay. Kallang Park Connector is part of the [Park Connector Network](/wiki/Park_Connector_Network) (PCN) managed by NParks, running from Bishan Road in the north to [Sims Avenue](/wiki/Sims_Avenue) in the south, largely following the course of the Kallang River. Constructed in 1995, it is the first park connector of its kind to be built and forms part of the Central Urban Loop. As their names imply, these park connectors aim to form a continuous loop which will eventually connect all the major parks within [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). Kallang Park Connector runs parallel to the Kallang River, except for the section around [Woodsville Interchange](/wiki/Woodsville_Interchange). It serves as a link between [Bishan–Ang Mo Kio Park](/wiki/Bishan-Ang_Mo_Kio_Park) and Kallang Riverside Park. Spanning 7.87 kilometres, Kallang Park Connector is the third longest park connector in Singapore, after Coastal Park Connector and Jurong Park Connector which are 15 kilometres-long and 9.4 kilometres-long respectively. Points of interest along Kallang Park Connector include Kallang River @ Bishan–Ang Mo Kio Park, as well as the Kolam Ayer ABC Waterfront. Plans to further rejuvenate the Kallang riverside, including the construction of bridges and underpasses to facilitate seamless connection across major traffic junctions, have been proposed. Other park connectors that run through Kallang include Geylang Park Connector, Pelton Canal Park Connector, Whampoa Park Connector and the Tanjong Rhu Promenade. [East Coast Park](/wiki/East_Coast_Park) is a coastal park that straddles the southeastern coast of Singapore, extending from [Marine Parade](/wiki/Marine_Parade) to [Tampines](/wiki/Tampines). Aside from serving the areas that it is located in, East Coast Park also serves various nearby communities like Kallang. East Coast Park can be accessed via Fort Road from Kallang. Located within the subzone of [Kampong Java](/wiki/Kampong_Java), at the junction of [Bukit Timah Road](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Road) and Cavenagh Road, was the Kampong Java Park. Like the Kallang Riverside Park, this park was maintained by NParks and featured a large pond as its centrepiece. In August 2018, the Kampong Java Park was permanently closed to facilitate the construction of the [North–South Corridor](/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Corridor,_Singapore) (NSC). ### Security The responsibility of maintaining security in Kallang is split among three police divisions of the [Singapore Police Force](/wiki/Singapore_Police_Force) (SPF): [Central Police Division](/wiki/Central_Police_Division), [Bedok Police Division](/wiki/Bedok_Police_Division) and [Tanglin Police Division](/wiki/Tanglin_Police_Division). The headquarters of the [Immigration and Checkpoints Authority](/wiki/Immigration_and_Checkpoints_Authority) (ICA) is located on [Kallang Road](/wiki/Kallang_Road), next to [Lavender MRT station](/wiki/Lavender_MRT_station). ### Fire department The [Singapore Civil Defence Force](/wiki/Singapore_Civil_Defence_Force) (SCDF) operates two fire posts in Kallang: - Boon Keng Fire Post - Mountbatten Fire Post The Mountbatten Fire Post along Kampong Arang Road was opened in June 2001, becoming the first fire post in Singapore. The former Serangoon Fire Station was built in 1952 and ceased operations in 2001. It was based at 1370 [Serangoon Road](/wiki/Serangoon_Road), in [Bendemeer](/wiki/Bendemeer) subzone. During the colonial era, [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore_in_the_Straits_Settlements#Crown_colony_(1867–1942))'s fire fighting duty came under the Singapore Fire Brigade. By 1909, three fire stations were set up across Singapore, including the now-demolished Kallang Fire Station (*not to be confused with the similarly named new Kallang Fire Station on Guillemard Close*). ### Postal service Three of the post offices managed by the [Singapore Post](/wiki/Singapore_Post) (SingPost) are based in Kallang: - City Square Post Office - Crawford Post Office - Towner Post Office SingPost's Kallang Delivery Base is located along Jalan Lembah Kallang. ## Housing As a result of Kallang's prime location just outside the [Central Area](/wiki/Central_Area,_Singapore), the [urban planning](/wiki/Urban_planning_in_Singapore) strategy and land use policy therefore differ from [towns](/wiki/New_towns_of_Singapore) that are established primarily for residential use (e.g. [Pasir Ris](/wiki/Pasir_Ris) and [Choa Chu Kang](/wiki/Choa_Chu_Kang)). Housing precincts appear to be "discontinuous" and "scattered" in Kallang, as compared to the aforementioned towns with "clustered" and "concentrated" residential neighbourhoods. In Kallang, lands set aside for residential developments may be punctuated with commercial, industrial or lifestyle areas, resulting in a disjointed town layout. Kallang is the main constituent unit of the Kallang/[Whampoa](/wiki/Whampoa,_Singapore) New Town as defined by the [Housing and Development Board](/wiki/Housing_and_Development_Board) (HDB). It is the only HDB town to extend across two separate [planning areas](/wiki/Planning_Areas_of_Singapore) (i.e. Kallang and [Novena](/wiki/Novena,_Singapore)). Previously, Kallang was classified as an "estate" but HDB later reorganised the area and promoted it to "new town" status. The first few residential precincts in Kallang, constructed by the HDB, were built in the 1970s and 1980s. Some housing blocks are planned to be reconstructed under the [Selective En bloc Redevelopment Scheme](/wiki/Selective_En_bloc_Redevelopment_Scheme) (SERS) to redevelop Kallang where the demographics are dominated by the middle-aged. New residential blocks which are around 30-storeys high are now prominent in the skyline of the area, with more being planned to be built under the new HDB construction policy. A notable major redevelopment is underway in the Old Kallang Airport Estate, where many of the low-rise blocks are currently unoccupied. New estates along Bendemeer Road and Upper Boon Keng Road are also popular options. Kallang/Whampoa is the fourth most expensive HDB new town in terms of rental prices. The rental price of a median 4-room HDB unit in Kallang/Whampoa is S$2500, compared to the national average of S$2120. Aside from [public housing](/wiki/Public_housing_in_Singapore) (flats) built by HDB, [condominiums](/wiki/Condominium_(living_space)) that provide high-end living options can be found primarily in [Tanjong Rhu](/wiki/Tanjong_Rhu), an affluent neighbourhood in southern Kallang. The precinct is in extreme close proximity to the [Central Area](/wiki/Central_Area,_Singapore) located across the [Kallang Basin](/wiki/Kallang_Basin) and [Marina Channel](/wiki/Marina_Channel), as well as [Gardens by the Bay](/wiki/Gardens_by_the_Bay) (Bay East Garden). Condominium clusters can also be found along Saint Michael's Road and Moonstone Lane, within the subzone of [Bendemeer](/wiki/Bendemeer,_Singapore). Car-free residential area will be piloted in the subzone of [Kampong Bugis](/wiki/Kampong_Bugis), at the mouth of [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River). These new blocks will be part of a fenceless pedestrian-friendly waterfront community that was announced by the [government](/wiki/Government_of_Singapore) in 2013. Around 4000 new housing units will be ready by 2030. Soil treatment work at the former [Kallang Gasworks](/wiki/Kallang_Gasworks) site began in November 2018 and is expected to conclude in July 2022. This accident became known as the "[Nicoll Highway collapse](/wiki/Nicoll_Highway_collapse)" and happened west of the [Merdeka Bridge](/wiki/Merdeka_Bridge,_Singapore), near present-day Nicoll Highway MRT station. #### Bus Kallang is served by an established [bus network](/wiki/Bus_transport_in_Singapore) that connects the area with other parts of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). Unlike other [towns](/wiki/New_towns_of_Singapore), Kallang does not have its own [feeder bus services](/wiki/List_of_bus_routes_in_Singapore#Types) which ply between the neighbourhoods of Kallang, likely due to the relatively fewer housing precincts in Kallang as compared to other new towns that are established primarily for residential purpose. [Lorong 1 Geylang Bus Terminal](/wiki/List_of_bus_stations_in_Singapore#Lorong_1_Geylang_Bus_Terminal) is the only bus terminal located in Kallang. It sits opposite [Kallang MRT station](/wiki/Kallang_MRT_station), along its namesake Lorong 1 Geylang. The Kallang area has no bus interchange or Integrated Transport Hub (ITH). The former [Crawford Street Bus Terminal](/wiki/List_of_former_bus_stations_in_Singapore#Others) was situated near the traffic junction of Crawford Street and [North Bridge Road](/wiki/North_Bridge_Road). Bus services that used to operate from this bus terminal were moved to Lorong 1 Geylang Bus Terminal when it ceased operations in 1998. ### Air travel Kallang played a significant role in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)'s aviation history, being the location of the country's first aircraft landing and home to its first purpose-built civil [airport](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Singapore), the [Kallang Airport](/wiki/Kallang_Airport). Opened on 12 June 1937 by [Sir Shenton Thomas](/wiki/Shenton_Thomas), the then-[Governor](/wiki/List_of_governors_of_the_Straits_Settlements) of the [Straits Settlements](/wiki/Straits_Settlements), Kallang Airport had the advantages of combined facilities for both land and marine aircraft. It was hailed as the "finest airport in the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire)" at that time. During its 18 years in service, the Kallang Airport played host to numerous high-profile celebrities such as [Governor](/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Singapore#Governors_of_Singapore_(1946–1959)) of [Singapore](/wiki/Colony_of_Singapore) [Sir John Fearns Nicoll](/wiki/John_Fearns_Nicoll), former [Premier](/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China) of [China](/wiki/China) [Zhou Enlai](/wiki/Zhou_Enlai), and renowned [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_people) businessman and philanthropist [Tan Kah Kee](/wiki/Tan_Kah_Kee), among others. Due to an increase in passenger traffic, the Singapore International Airport (modern-day [Paya Lebar Air Base](/wiki/Paya_Lebar_Air_Base)) was later built in [Paya Lebar](/wiki/Paya_Lebar) to replace the Kallang Airport which eventually ceased operations in 1955. The airport's terminal building was conserved alongside the hangar, gate posts, lamp posts and several other buildings. The terminal building was subsequently converted into the [People's Association](/wiki/People%27s_Association_(Singapore)) (PA) headquarters on 1 July 1960. The organisation occupied the building until 6 April 2009 when it moved to its current location at King George's Avenue, also in Kallang. Other groups that used to be based at the Kallang Airport site include the Singapore Youth Sports Council, the Public Works Department (the predecessor of [CPG Corporation](/wiki/CPG_Corporation)) and Central Manpower Base (CMPB). The conserved Kallang Airport complex is currently unoccupied and restricted from public access. Today, legacies of the old Kallang Airport remain. Roads such as [Old Airport Road](/wiki/Old_Airport_Road,_Singapore) (named as such because it was the eastern boundary of the Kallang Airport), Kallang Airport Drive, Kallang Airport Way and Old Terminal Lane bear reference to the Kallang Airport. A signboard with the words "Kallang Airport" is standing at the junction of Old Airport Road and Cassia Link, in front of 95 Old Airport Road. [Dakota Crescent](/wiki/Dakota_Crescent), Dakota Close and [Dakota MRT station](/wiki/Dakota_MRT_station) are named after the [Douglas DC-3 "Dakota"](/wiki/Douglas_DC-3) aircraft that used to frequently land at the Kallang Airport, and serve to commemorate an aviation disaster in 1946. The residential precincts on either side of Old Airport Road are collectively called the "Old Kallang Airport Estate". The conserved Kallang Airport building was one of the hosting venues of the 2011 [Singapore Biennale](/wiki/Singapore_Biennale). The decision to hold this art festival at the old Kallang Airport was controversial, with negative opinions surrounding the building's poor ventilation and inaccessibility. There are plans to redevelop the Kallang Airport area into a commercial hub, along with the nearby Kallang riverside. This proposed plan is known as "Old Airport Square", as envisioned by the [Urban Redevelopment Authority](/wiki/Urban_Redevelopment_Authority) (URA) Master Plan 2008. Predating the Kallang Airport, Singapore's first aircraft landing took place at the [Farrer Park Field](/wiki/Farrer_Park_Field) on 4 December 1919, when [Captain Ross Smith](/wiki/Ross_Macpherson_Smith) touched down in a [Vickers Vimy](/wiki/Vickers_Vimy) along with three other crew members. ## Sports Kallang occupies an important position in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)'s sporting culture and history, particularly due to the several iconic [sports locations](/wiki/List_of_stadiums_in_Singapore) sited within its boundaries, as well as the numerous high-profile sporting events held there. Famous sports facilities include the [old National Stadium](/wiki/Former_National_Stadium,_Singapore), the [Jalan Besar Stadium](/wiki/Jalan_Besar_Stadium), the [Farrer Park Field](/wiki/Farrer_Park_Field), and the [Singapore Sports Hub](/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub). Kallang is notable for being the location of the former National Stadium (nicknamed the "Grand Old Dame of Kallang") and the new Singapore Sports Hub which was built on the same site to replace the former. The latter is the flagship development in Kallang and includes the [new National Stadium](/wiki/National_Stadium,_Singapore), the [Singapore Indoor Stadium](/wiki/Singapore_Indoor_Stadium), the OCBC Aquatic Centre, the OCBC Arena, the [Kallang Wave Mall](/wiki/Kallang_Wave_Mall), the Singapore Sports Museum, the Sports Hub Library, as well as several other sports facilities. The Singapore Sports Hub is the only "Tier 1" facility under the Sports Facilities Master Plan. The [Singapore national football team](/wiki/Singapore_national_football_team) is based at the new National Stadium. Aside from being a traditional location for hosting the [National Day Parade](/wiki/Singapore_National_Day_Parade) (NDP), the old National Stadium also played host to numerous notable cultural and sports events, including those of the [Malaysia Cup](/wiki/Malaysia_Cup), where loud cheers and stamping of feet gave birth to the famous "Kallang Roar". The famous "Kallang Wave" is a type of [Mexican wave](/wiki/Wave_(audience)) that often took place in the old National Stadium during those games. Both the Kallang Roar and Kallang Wave are considered to be symbols of national unity. The (/wiki/1973_Southeast_Asian_Games), (/wiki/1983_Southeast_Asian_Games) and (/wiki/1993_Southeast_Asian_Games) [Southeast Asian Games](/wiki/Southeast_Asian_Games) used the old National Stadium as its ceremony venue. The future Kallang Football Hub will replace the current [Kallang Field](/wiki/Kallang_Field), and is expected to be ready by the third quarter of 2019. It will incorporate three full-sized football pitches, four sheltered futsal pitches, a running track and a gymnasium. Other than serving as an alternative training ground for the Singapore national football team, the Kallang Football Hub will also be open to the public. The [Kallang Ground](/wiki/Kallang_Ground) is another sporting venue located in Kallang, and has played host to several [One Day International](/wiki/One_Day_International) cricket matches. In more recent times, it is mainly used to host domestic competitions and minor international matches such as those between Singapore and [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia). Kallang Ground was home to the [Singapore national cricket team](/wiki/Singapore_national_cricket_team) for 21 years. [Netball](/wiki/Netball_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), [basketball](/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), [fencing](/wiki/Fencing_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), [indoor volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), as well as the [billiards and snooker](/wiki/Billiards_and_snooker_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games) games were conducted at the OCBC Arena. The Singapore Indoor Stadium held the [badminton](/wiki/Badminton_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games) and [table tennis](/wiki/Table_tennis_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games) matches. The OCBC Aquatic Centre was the location of the [diving](/wiki/Diving_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), [swimming](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), [synchronised swimming](/wiki/Synchronised_swimming_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games) and [water polo](/wiki/Water_polo_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games) games. The Kallang Squash Centre, Kallang Tennis Centre, Kallang Ground, Kallang Field and Kallang Practice Track hosted the [squash](/wiki/Squash_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), [tennis](/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), [archery](/wiki/Archery_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games), [softball](/wiki/Softball_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games) and marathon games respectively. Jalan Besar Stadium also conducted the football games, in addition to the new National Stadium. ## Future developments The [Urban Redevelopment Authority](/wiki/Urban_Redevelopment_Authority) (URA) has proposed to transform Kallang into a lifestyle and commercial hub, with the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River) and [Singapore Sports Hub](/wiki/Singapore_Sports_Hub) as the centrepieces of the town. ### Residential Over the next two decades, around 100,000 new housing units will be built. [Kampong Bugis](/wiki/Kampong_Bugis) will be developed into a car-lite waterfront community. New housing estates are also planned at [Dakota Crescent](/wiki/Dakota_Crescent), Lorong 3 Geylang and the area now occupied by the [Farrer Park Field](/wiki/Farrer_Park_Field). ### Lifestyle A new promenade along the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River) has been announced. It aims to seamlessly connect areas at the upstream of the river such as [Bishan](/wiki/Bishan,_Singapore) to the [Downtown Core](/wiki/Downtown_Core). More specifically, the construction of underpasses and bridges have been proposed as viable options to improve the connectivity at major traffic junctions. ### Connectivity Two new [Mass Rapid Transit](/wiki/Mass_Rapid_Transit_(Singapore)) (MRT) stations, namely [Tanjong Rhu MRT station](/wiki/Tanjong_Rhu_MRT_station) and [Katong Park MRT station](/wiki/Katong_Park_MRT_station), on the [Thomson–East Coast Line](/wiki/Thomson%E2%80%93East_Coast_Line) are under construction. Once ready by 2023, these two stations will serve southern Kallang, particularly the affluent communities along Tanjong Rhu Road. The upcoming [North–South Corridor](/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Corridor,_Singapore) (NSC) will enhance connectivity between Kallang, [Toa Payoh](/wiki/Toa_Payoh), [Bishan](/wiki/Bishan,_Singapore), [Ang Mo Kio](/wiki/Ang_Mo_Kio), [Yishun](/wiki/Yishun) and [Woodlands](/wiki/Woodlands,_Singapore). It is slated for completion in 2026. ### Amenities The upcoming Kallang Fire Station situated at the junction of Guillemard Road and Guillemard Close will be the 22nd fire station operated by the [Singapore Civil Defence Force](/wiki/Singapore_Civil_Defence_Force) (SCDF), with a target completion date in 2019. Other than hosting the fire department, Kallang Fire Station will also house a Home Team Joint Facility, which will act as a key command for the Home Team during major event standbys and joint operations in Kallang. A new 10-storey polyclinic will be built in Kallang by 2020, as announced by the [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore)) (MOH). It will be located near the junction of [Serangoon Road](/wiki/Serangoon_Road) and Balestier Road, adjacent to Kwong Wai Shiu Hospital. ### Master Plan 2014 According to the [Urban Redevelopment Authority](/wiki/Urban_Redevelopment_Authority) (URA) Master Plan 2014, the following lands in Kallang will see future redevelopment: - Geylang Bahru Industrial Estate along Geylang Bahru Terrace is marked as a residential site, as is the land currently occupied by the Kallang Distripark; - Land parcels on the eastern bank of the [Kallang River](/wiki/Kallang_River), along Old Terminal Lane and Stadium Road, are marked as hotel sites; - Lands around the conserved [Kallang Airport](/wiki/Kallang_Airport) complex are marked as "white" sites which allow for more flexible planning (white sites are rare outside of the [Central Area](/wiki/Central_Area,_Singapore)); - Lands along [Nicoll Highway](/wiki/Nicoll_Highway), Republic Avenue and Republic Boulevard are reserve sites, as are the lands between the Kallang River and Kallang Place, as well as those along [Jalan Benaan Kapal](/wiki/Jalan_Benaan_Kapal) and Stadium Crescent. ## Popular culture Kallang is heavily featured in the 2008 sports film *[Kallang Roar the Movie](/wiki/Kallang_Roar_the_Movie)*, of which the events leading up to [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) winning the 1977 [Malaysia Cup](/wiki/Malaysia_Cup) take centrestage. Filming took place at the [old National Stadium](/wiki/Former_National_Stadium,_Singapore) where some of the football matches happened. The 2016 [Mediacorp](/wiki/Mediacorp) drama [*Hero*](/wiki/Hero_(2016_TV_series)) is set primarily in the residential precinct of [Dakota Crescent](/wiki/Dakota_Crescent), within the Old Kallang Airport Estate. ## Sources - Victor R Savage, Brenda S A Yeoh (2003), *Toponymics – A Study of Singapore Street Names*, Eastern Universities Press, [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 981-210-205-1 Media related to Kallang at Wikimedia Commons
